channel.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
channel.description:
The plans for a no fly zone over Libya Britain and France have been trying to push over the past week or two have finally got *firm* backing from the US and the UN.
Didn't expect to see a result this early..
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12779628

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:39, topic:386773”]http://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFLDE72I0OF20110319

Gaddafi says he will arm Libyan civilians to defend against crusaders.[/quote]

the article is 100% propoganda by gaddafi to gain support and try to unify a nation against a common enemy hence why most people share the view that no ground troops should land in libya, the no fly zone (should) be strictly against gaddafi’s airforce and troops, not the common citizens, ‘rebels’ or anyone else

[quote=“Frell, post:43, topic:386773”]But theyre not really resisting anything, theyre pushing :\

But I get it yea[/quote]

[quote=“Frell, post:45, topic:386773”]That they provoked though

Im not against the event just the terminology lol[/quote]

peaceful protests do not justify military intervention edit: hence saying they provoked it is just wrong

Read full topic

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

[quote=“goatee, post:46, topic:386773”]I have a strange feeling that maybe these “rebels” are actually a minority of insurgents and gangs that are threatening the stability of the whole country by manipulating western media views using propaganda and that revolution is not what the majority want. We may have made a terrible mistake by supporting these people.

On the other hand Gaddafi is bat shit crazy so I don’t know what to believe.[/quote]

I would have also had that notion if it wasn’t for two things. Firstly, people have got to be pretty damn stupid to be in favour of Ghadafi. Secondly, I have a few Libyan friends who all share the same beliefs regarding Ghadafi.

I find France’s devotion in support of the resistance suspicious. What do those Muslim-hating Frenchies want?

BBC: US F-15 crash landed in Libya

Read full topic

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Finally, American and British capabilities are put to good use.

I don’t see this ending up like Iraq or Afghanistan because unlike those wars, the people of Libya mostly oppose Gaddafi. Furthermore, Gaddafi is much more evil than Saddam and he needs to be removed.

The only thing that could make things go south is the presence of ground troops.

[quote=“Pwnd, post:22, topic:386773”][quote author=Radeon link=topic=482544.msg3534190#msg3534190 date=1300423976]
Too late. If this happened earlier, the resistance may have had a chance.
[/quote]The resistance ahahahaha.

Yo, dude, people are so fucking stupid, forealz. No fly zone just means that we’re going to be bombing to shit out of their people. Ah, this fucking world dude. Then we’re going to instill a new dictator, and if he doesn’t play ball, we just Saddam the shit out of them.[/quote]
I am hopeful that the fact that there won’t be any foreign troops on the ground and that the resistance started before foreign intervention, means that it is unlikely a dictator will be instilled. I am only hopeful and things could change very quickly.

Read full topic
item.source: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Thug-life, post:33, topic:386773”]From my perspective, Obama’s current stance is purposely made to be the way it is. The United States doesn’t want to seem to be taking the lead on this assault for many political reasons, and what Obama seemingly promised during the elections. This is echoed in what that guy from the US military (some commander, I think) was saying in the press conference at the pentagon, that this isn’t another US led attack, it is a coalition effort that will be under coalition command within the next few days.

Obama is being cautious to reflect the stance he wants to country to appear to be taking.[/quote]
Oh god no its not just this, its everything else also. Obama took too long to make a decision and it cost peoples lives so another country had to stand up and do something.

MARCH 19, 2011
OBAMA: ‘Today we are part of a broad coalition. We are answering the calls of a threatened people. And we are acting in the interests of the United States and the world’…

MARCH 19, 2003
BUSH: ‘American and coalition forces are in the early stages of military operations to disarm Iraq, to free its people and to defend the world from grave danger’…

Read full topic

“British Submarines and US Warships fire more than 110 missiles at Libyan air defence bases”

“Libyan state TV reports that ‘crusader enemies’ are bombing civilian targets”
[/quote]

Libyan TV Also said a French Warplane got shot down. Check the videos, Looks nothing like a Rafale[/quote]

Yeah, it was a plane held by the opposition and it was shot down by Gaddafi.

item.title: UN set to back British and French plans for Libyan no fly zone
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

From my perspective, Obama’s current stance is purposely made to be the way it is. The United States doesn’t want to seem to be taking the lead on this assault for many political reasons, and what Obama seemingly promised during the elections. This is echoed in what that guy from the US military (some commander, I think) was saying in the press conference at the pentagon, that this isn’t another US led attack, it is a coalition effort that will be under coalition command within the next few days.

Obama is being cautious to reflect the stance he wants to country to appear to be taking.

Read full topic

item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Trust me, you don’t want a woman leading your country.

Female New South Wales premier.
Female Queensland premier.
Female Tasmanian premier.
Female prime minister. Female governor general.
No wonder Australia floods once a month and goes off like a cyclone.

tl;dr: Don’t make the same mistake that we did by voting a woman into the position that actually gets to call the shots.

item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

He canceled the speech in Rio square and the press conference.

Anytime theres something going on he goes into hiding, he makes small little video speeches with promises that never follow through. Hilary Clinton has finally publicly announced she is tired of him and his indecision. But watch, if something good comes out of this Libyan thing he will make numerous speeches and thank his administration and take credit for it.

I really hope Hilary runs against him next year and at the least she makes it into the white house, anyone but him.
